subclusters.subcluster_name: Immunosenescence as a Causal Driver of Systemic Aging Theory
Thymic Involution and Immune Aging Theory

theory_assignments.reasoning: This theory focuses on immune system aging (immunosenescence) and chronic low-grade inflammation (inflammaging) as central drivers of aging.
Describes immunosenescence and inflammaging as interconnected mechanisms driving systemic aging and reduced vaccine efficacy.
Explicitly links immunosenescence and inflammaging as joint contributors to aging and age-related diseases.
Focuses on immune aging, inflammaging, and metabolic dysregulation in immune cells as aging mechanisms.
Describes immune compositional changes, inflammaging, and tertiary lymphoid structures as hallmarks of immune aging.
Focuses on immunosenescence and inflammaging, including hyperinflammatory responses in COVID-19 as aging mechanisms.
Details age-related immune decline and inflammaging leading to increased infection and cancer risk.
Shows immunosenescence and inflammaging in a free-living animal model with links to oxidative stress.
Connects immunosenescence-driven chronic inflammation to systemic dysfunction and fatigue.
Links immunosenescence and inflammaging to lung diseases and systemic aging.
Describes immunosenescence and inflammaging as convergent pathways in neurodegeneration.
Focuses on Rcor2 epigenetic regulation of inflammatory gene expression driving inflammaging, a specific mechanistic angle within inflammaging.
Links chronic inflammation and immune-mediated oxidative stress to accelerated aging, fitting with inflammation-driven aging.
Focuses on cytokine gene polymorphisms regulating immune balance and inflammation influencing aging and longevity.
Describes how exercise improves immune function, delays immunosenescence, and reduces inflammaging.
Details exercise-induced removal of senescent T cells, thymic stimulation, and anti-inflammatory effects countering immunosenescence.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Immunosenescence as a Causal Driver of Systemic Aging Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Proposes immune competence decline as a causal driver of systemic aging, including lymphoid organ aging and sex differences.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Immunosenescence as a Causal Driver of Systemic Aging Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Shows immunosenescence causing systemic aging and organ-specific degeneration, with immune rejuvenation preventing age-related hearing loss.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Immunosenescence as a Causal Driver of Systemic Aging Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Positions immunosenescence as a master regulator of systemic aging, linking oxidative damage, mitochondrial dysfunction, and nutrition.
Focuses on immunosenescence in autoimmune diseases, including senescent immune cells, SASP, mitochondrial dysfunction, and bidirectional disease interactions.
Describes immune remodeling with age, increased autoantibody production, and autoimmune manifestations contributing to aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Thymic Involution and Immune Aging Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on chronic perdurated thymic involution post-puberty causing immune decline and systemic aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Thymic Involution and Immune Aging Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes genetically programmed thymic involution and endocrine regulation leading to immune decline and age-related diseases.
Focuses on recurrent childhood infections causing premature immunosenescence, thymic atrophy, and immune dysregulation.
Describes immune responses to somatic mutation-generated neo-antigens causing tissue damage and contributing to aging.
